content:
ivorced.
In uttering sentences of this kind, the speaker thereby doessomething more
than merely statingsomething. The philosopher J. L. Austin labeled such utter-
ances performativesin  order  to  contrast  performing  an  action  with  simply
describing something.2For example, if an umpire shouts, “You’re out!” then
the batter is out. The umpire is not merely describing the situation but declaring
the batter out. By way of contrast, if someone in the stands shouts, “He’s out!”
the batter is not
